sense.name: have or cause to have impaired or blocked respiration
sense.commentary: Note: The thing having its respiration blocked must be animate.
sense.examples: The foul air is choking the children. The canary choked on the poisoned air. The collar was choking the cat. The suspect told police he didn't mean to choke her. She choked on a pretzel and passed out.

sense.name: have difficulty breathing or speaking due to strong emotions
sense.examples: He choked with emotion as he praised the staff. I always get choked up at weddings.

sense.name: become or cause to become obstructed
sense.commentary: Note: The thing choked is inanimate.
sense.examples: The gutters were choked with leaves. The tulips were choked by weeds. I25 is always choked with commuters this time of day. Small roots penetrate the bag, but they are choked off as they increase in diameter. Public hospitals are choked up with bludgers lining up with head colds instead of paying to see a GP.

sense.name: suppress, check or trap
sense.examples: She choked her anger. I asked him how he was doing, and he choked back a sob. He choked down his fear just to put on the harness. He choked off unneeded imports so decisively that the country showed a favorable balance of trade that year. Mary is choking John with all her affection. Lionel's job is choking him.

sense.name: change one's grip
sense.examples: You'll get more force if you choke up on the bat. He choked down on his driver and gently pulled his club back over the top.

sense.name: reduce the air intake of a carburetor
sense.examples: It lacks a great deal of explanation covering how to choke the carburetor.

sense.name: fail to preform adequately due to tension
sense.examples: The team choked in the final inning. It was up to Hans to win the game, but at the last minute he choked.
